Title: Perirhinal and parahippocampal cortices of the macaque monkey: Cortical afferents
Abstract: Neuropsychological studies have recently demonstrated that the macaque monkey perirhinal (areas 35 and 36) and parahippocampal (areas TH and TF) cortices contribute importantly to normal memory function. Unfortunately, neuroanatomical information concerning the cytoarchitectonic organization and extrinsic connectivity of these cortical regions is meager. We investigated the organization of cortical inputs to the macaque monkey perirhinal and parahippocampal cortices by placing discrete injections of the retrograde tracers fast blue, diamidino yellow, and wheat germ agglutinin conjugated to horseradish peroxidase throughout these areas. We found that the macaque monkey perirhinal and parahippocampal cortices receive different complements of cortical inputs. The major cortical inputs to the perirhinal cortex arise from the unimodal visual areas TE and rostral TEO and from area TF of the parahippocampal cortex. The perirhinal cortex also receives projections from the dysgranular and granular subdivisions of the insular cortex and from area 13 of the orbitofrontal cortex. In contrast, area TF of the parahippocampal cortex receives its strongest input from more caudal visual areas V4, TEO, and caudal TE, as well as prominent inputs from polymodal association cortices, including the retrosplenial cortex and the dorsal bank of the superior temporal sulcus. Area TF also receives projections from areas 7a and LIP of the posterior parietal lobe, insular cortex, and areas 46, 13, 45, and 9 of the frontal lobe. As with area TF, area TH receives substantial projections from the retrosplenial cortex as well as moderate projections from the dorsal bank of the superior temporal sulcus; unlike area TF, area TH receives almost no innervation from areas TE and TEO. It does, however, receive relatively strong inputs from auditory association areas on the convexity of the superior temporal gyrus.

@InterMapRelations.Comments: It is not clearly stated from which parcellation scheme area STG is adopted. Because IAC87a has been cited in the section of the text where STG is described and D.G. Amaral is a common author of both papers, we chose the parcellation scheme of IAC87a to relate area SA94-STG to subdivisions. SA94-STG extends from the superior lip of the STS to the fundus of the sulcus lateralis and does not include any part of the STS and not the fundus of the sulcus lateralis. Because of that area STG of S94 contains IAC87a' s areas STGr, STGo, STGl, LA, PA, AI, and RA.

"The parahippocampal cortex is caudally adjacent to both the entorhinal cortex and the perirhinal cortex and is made up of a smaller, medially situated area TH and a larger, laterally situated area TF (Fig. 1B). Arae TH has been divided into a rostral subdivision (area THr) and a caudal subdivision (area THc; Fig. 3A). ...We have subdivided area TF into areas TFm (medial subdivision of area TF) and TFl (lateral subdivision of area TF; Fig. 3A). " (p. 502)

"The parahippocampal cortex is caudally adjacent to both the entorhinal cortex and the perirhinal cortex and is made up of a smaller, medially situated area TH and a larger, laterally situated area TF (Fig. 1B). Arae TH has been divided into a rostral subdivision (area THr) and a caudal subdivision (area THc; Fig. 3A). ...We have subdivided area TF into areas TFm (medial subdivision of area TF) and TFl (lateral subdivision of area TF; Fig. 3A). " (p. 502)

Arae TH has been divided into a rostral subdivision (area THr) and a caudal subdivision (area THc; Fig. 3A). ...We have subdivided area TF into areas TFm (medial subdivision of area TF) and TFl (lateral subdivision of area TF; Fig. 3A). "Area V4 gives rise to a moderate to strong projection to all levels of areas TF and TH. In all cases (Fig. 11A-E), it is a rather restricted region of area V4, located just caudal to the caudal boundary of area TF, that gives rise to these projections. This most rostral portion of area V4 may correspond to an area Boussaoud et al. (1991) have referred to as area VTF (see also Gattass et al., 1985). Only occasional labeled cells were observed more caudally in area V4." (p. 511) " Following retrograde tracer injections in area TF, the number of labeled cells in area V4 was highest in a relatively small rostrocaudal region of cortex situated just caudal to the caudal boundary of area TF. This area may correspond to area VTF (a caudal, visual responsive area of TF) of Boussaoud et al. (1991), also referred to as area VF of Gattass et al. (1985). Boussaoud et al. (1991) reported that area TFVTF contains a representation of the central visual field. In contrast to area TF, area TH receives a relatively smaller projection from visual areas. However, the strongest projection originates from the same anteriorly situated portion of area V4 (possibly area VTF) that projects heavily to area TF." (p. 521)

"Area 36 is located just lateral to area 35 and has been parceled into five subdivisions (Fig. 3A). Area 36d (the dorsal subdivision of area 36) is located at the most rostral and dorsal extent of the perirhinal cortex (Fig. 1A) and makes up approximately the dorsal one-third of what is typically referred to as the temporal pole (area 38 of Brodmann; area TG of Bonin and Bailey, 1947). ...Caudally, adjacent to area 36d, is area 36r (rostral subdivision of area 36). Area 36r has been further subdivided in area 36rm (rostromedial subdivision of area 36) and area 36rl (rostrolateral subdivision of area 36).Area 36rm is situated lateral to area 35, is relatively narrow in the mediolateral axis, and is bordered laterally along its full rostocaudal extent by area 36rl ... Area 36rl is the largest of the subdivisions of area 36. ...At its most rostral and dorsal extent, it makes up approximately the ventral two-thirds of what is typically referred to as the temporal pole (most of what is labeled 36r in Fig. 1A, area 38 of Brodmann, 1909; area TG of Bonin and Bailey, 1947). It is bounded laterally by the unimodal visual area TE. Ventrally, area 36rl is situated at the same level as approximately the rostral one-half of the entorhinal cortex (Figs. 1B, 3A). ...The caudal extreme of the perirhinal cortex is called area 36c (caudal subdivision of area 36; Fig. 1B). As with area 36r, we have identified medial and lateral portions of area 36c: area 36cm (caudomedial subdivision of area 36; Fig. 3A).Area 36cm is laterally adjacent to the intermediate and caudal divisions of the entorhinal cortex (areas EI and EC), and area 36cl is typically bounded laterally by the rostral pole of area TF. ...It should be noted that the area encompassed by the perirhinal cortex, as defined here, is substantially larger than illustrated in previous papers on this region ... This due largely to the fact that we have placed the border of the perirhinal cortex with area TE substantially more lateral than is typically the case. The judgement to place the border at this position is based on the findings that the entire region that we have defined as the perirhinal cortex has similar connections both with the entorhinal cortex and with the neocortex. These connections seem to be substantially different from those of the laterally adjacent area TE. Historically, much of what we have labeled perirhinal cortex has been included under the rubric of "inferotemporal cortex" (IT cortex or area TE)." (p. 502) "...; TE, area TE of Bonin and Bailey" (p. 501, figure)

@InterMapRelations.Comments: Because of the location of the lateral border of the perirhinal cortex in SA94, area TE of SA94 is smaller than area TE of BB47.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "It should be noted that approximately the medial half of area TE1 of Seltzer and Pandya (1978) corresponds to approximately the lateral half of what we have labeled as area 36 of the perirhinal cortex." (p. 503)

@InterMapRelations.Comments: It is nowhere stated, from which parcellation scheme area 35 is adopted, but it seems that it corresponds to area 35 of AIC87, because (i) both areas have the same location, (ii) both papers have a common author (D.G. Amaral), and AIC87 has been already cited in this paper.

It is not clearly stated, from which parcellation scheme area PaS (parasubiculum) is adopted, but it is quite certain that area PaS of SA94 is identical with area PaS of IAC87a, because (i) they have the same location, (ii) a common author (D.G. Amaral), the same abbreviation, and (iv) IAC87a has been already cited in this paper.

It is not clearly stated, from which parcellation scheme area TEO is adopted, but it seems that it corresponds to area TEO of BB47, because (i) they have the same name, (ii) approximately the same location, and (iii) BB47 has been already cited in this paper.

It seems that area TF of SA94  is identical with area TF of BB47, because (i) both areas have the same name, (ii) the same location, (iii) BB47 is a classic reference for the description of the parahippocampal gyrus, and (iv) BB47 has been already cited in this paper.

It seems that area TF of SA94  is identical with area TF of BB47, because (i) both areas have the same name, (ii) the same location, (iii) BB47 is a classic reference for the description of the parahippocampal gyrus, and (iv) BB47 has been already cited in this paper.

@InterMapRelations.Comments: It is not only ambiguous, that area TF of SA94 is identical with area 21, because both areas are only juxtaposed textually, so they could also have an another relation, but it is also not clear, from which parcellation scheme area 21 is adopted. It seems that area 21 corresponds to area 21 of B09, because (i) they have the same label, (ii) the same location, and (iii) B09 has been already cited in this paper for the description of cortical areas. And if area 21 of B09 is meant, it is quite possible, that both areas are identical, because they have roughly the same location.
@InterMapRelations.Corrected_Why:
"Jones and Powell (1970) initially reported weak projections from the lateral portion of area TE (area 21) to area 35." (p. 520)
The usual confusion, is lateral portion of TE equal to 21 or TE itself? This statement conflicts with many others, so scrap it.

"Area 36 is located just lateral to area 35 and has been parceled into five subdivisions (Fig. 3A). Area 36d (the dorsal subdivision of area 36) is located at the most rostral and dorsal extent of the perirhinal cortex (Fig. 1A) and makes up approximately the dorsal one-third of what is typically referred to as the temporal pole (area 38 of Brodmann; area TG of Bonin and Bailey, 1947). ...Caudally, adjacent to area 36d, is area 36r (rostral subdivision of area 36). Area 36r has been further subdivided in area 36rm (rostromedial subdivision of area 36) and area 36rl (rostrolateral subdivision of area 36).Area 36rm is situated lateral to area 35, is relatively narrow in the mediolateral axis, and is bordered laterally along its full rostocaudal extent by area 36rl ... Area 36rl is the largest of the subdivisions of area 36. ...At its most rostral and dorsal extent, it makes up approximately the ventral two-thirds of what is typically referred to as the temporal pole (most of what is labeled 36r in Fig. 1A, area 38 of Brodmann, 1909; area TG of Bonin and Bailey, 1947). It is bounded laterally by the unimodal visual area TE. Ventrally, area 36rl is situated at the same level as approximately the rostral one-half of the entorhinal cortex (Figs. 1B, 3A). ...The caudal extreme of the perirhinal cortex is called area 36c (caudal subdivision of area 36; Fig. 1B). As with area 36r, we have identified medial and lateral portions of area 36c: area 36cm (caudomedial subdivision of area 36; Fig. 3A).Area 36cm is laterally adjacent to the intermediate and caudal divisions of the entorhinal cortex (areas EI and EC), and area 36cl is typically bounded laterally by the rostral pole of area TF. ...It should be noted that the area encompassed by the perirhinal cortex, as defined here, is substantially larger than illustrated in previous papers on this region ... This due largely to the fact that we have placed the border of the perirhinal cortex with area TE substantially more lateral than is typically the case. The judgement to place the border at this position is based on the findings that the entire region that we have defined as the perirhinal cortex has similar connections both with the entorhinal cortex and with the neocortex. These connections seem to be substantially different from those of the laterally adjacent area TE. Historically, much of what we have labeled perirhinal cortex has been included under the rubric of "inferotemporal cortex" (IT cortex or area TE)." (p. 502)

@InterMapRelations.Comments: It is not clearly stated from which parcellation scheme area STG is adopted. Because IAC87a has been cited in the section of the text where STG is described and D.G. Amaral is a common author of both papers, we chose the parcellation scheme of IAC87a to relate area SA94-STG to subdivisions. SA94-STG extends from the superior lip of the STS to the fundus of the sulcus lateralis and does not include any part of the STS and not the fundus of the sulcus lateralis. Because of that area STG of S94 contains IAC87a' s areas STGr, STGo, STGl, LA, PA, AI, and RA.

"Area V4 gives rise to a moderate to strong projection to all levels of areas TF and TH. In all cases (Fig. 11A-E), it is a rather restricted region of area V4, located just caudal to the caudal boundary of area TF, that gives rise to these projections. This most rostral portion of area V4 may correspond to an area Boussaoud et al. (1991) have referred to as area VTF (see also Gattass et al., 1985). Only occasional labeled cells were observed more caudally in area V4." (p. 511) " Following retrograde tracer injections in area TF, the number of labeled cells in area V4 was highest in a relatively small rostrocaudal region of cortex situated just caudal to the caudal boundary of area TF. This area may correspond to area VTF (a caudal, visual responsive area of TF) of Boussaoud et al. (1991), also referred to as area VF of Gattass et al. (1985). Boussaoud et al. (1991) reported that area TFVTF contains a representation of the central visual field. In contrast to area TF, area TH receives a relatively smaller projection from visual areas. However, the strongest projection originates from the same anteriorly situated portion of area V4 (possibly area VTF) that projects heavily to area TF." (p. 521)

"Area 36 is located just lateral to area 35 and has been parceled into five subdivisions (Fig. 3A). Area 36d (the dorsal subdivision of area 36) is located at the most rostral and dorsal extent of the perirhinal cortex (Fig. 1A) and makes up approximately the dorsal one-third of what is typically referred to as the temporal pole (area 38 of Brodmann; area TG of Bonin and Bailey, 1947). ...Caudally, adjacent to area 36d, is area 36r (rostral subdivision of area 36). Area 36r has been further subdivided in area 36rm (rostromedial subdivision of area 36) and area 36rl (rostrolateral subdivision of area 36).Area 36rm is situated lateral to area 35, is relatively narrow in the mediolateral axis, and is bordered laterally along its full rostocaudal extent by area 36rl ... Area 36rl is the largest of the subdivisions of area 36. ...At its most rostral and dorsal extent, it makes up approximately the ventral two-thirds of what is typically referred to as the temporal pole (most of what is labeled 36r in Fig. 1A, area 38 of Brodmann, 1909; area TG of Bonin and Bailey, 1947). It is bounded laterally by the unimodal visual area TE. Ventrally, area 36rl is situated at the same level as approximately the rostral one-half of the entorhinal cortex (Figs. 1B, 3A). ...The caudal extreme of the perirhinal cortex is called area 36c (caudal subdivision of area 36; Fig. 1B). As with area 36r, we have identified medial and lateral portions of area 36c: area 36cm (caudomedial subdivision of area 36; Fig. 3A).Area 36cm is laterally adjacent to the intermediate and caudal divisions of the entorhinal cortex (areas EI and EC), and area 36cl is typically bounded laterally by the rostral pole of area TF. ...It should be noted that the area encompassed by the perirhinal cortex, as defined here, is substantially larger than illustrated in previous papers on this region ... This due largely to the fact that we have placed the border of the perirhinal cortex with area TE substantially more lateral than is typically the case. The judgement to place the border at this position is based on the findings that the entire region that we have defined as the perirhinal cortex has similar connections both with the entorhinal cortex and with the neocortex. These connections seem to be substantially different from those of the laterally adjacent area TE. Historically, much of what we have labeled perirhinal cortex has been included under the rubric of "inferotemporal cortex" (IT cortex or area TE)." (p. 502) "...; TE, area TE of Bonin and Bailey" (p. 501, figure)

It seems that area TF of SA94  is identical with area TF of BB47, because (i) both areas have the same name, (ii) the same location, (iii) BB47 is a classic reference for the description of the parahippocampal gyrus, and (iv) BB47 has been already cited in this paper.

"Area 36 is located just lateral to area 35 and has been parceled into five subdivisions (Fig. 3A). Area 36d (the dorsal subdivision of area 36) is located at the most rostral and dorsal extent of the perirhinal cortex (Fig. 1A) and makes up approximately the dorsal one-third of what is typically referred to as the temporal pole (area 38 of Brodmann; area TG of Bonin and Bailey, 1947). ...Caudally, adjacent to area 36d, is area 36r (rostral subdivision of area 36). Area 36r has been further subdivided in area 36rm (rostromedial subdivision of area 36) and area 36rl (rostrolateral subdivision of area 36).Area 36rm is situated lateral to area 35, is relatively narrow in the mediolateral axis, and is bordered laterally along its full rostocaudal extent by area 36rl ... Area 36rl is the largest of the subdivisions of area 36. ...At its most rostral and dorsal extent, it makes up approximately the ventral two-thirds of what is typically referred to as the temporal pole (most of what is labeled 36r in Fig. 1A, area 38 of Brodmann, 1909; area TG of Bonin and Bailey, 1947). It is bounded laterally by the unimodal visual area TE. Ventrally, area 36rl is situated at the same level as approximately the rostral one-half of the entorhinal cortex (Figs. 1B, 3A). ...The caudal extreme of the perirhinal cortex is called area 36c (caudal subdivision of area 36; Fig. 1B). As with area 36r, we have identified medial and lateral portions of area 36c: area 36cm (caudomedial subdivision of area 36; Fig. 3A).Area 36cm is laterally adjacent to the intermediate and caudal divisions of the entorhinal cortex (areas EI and EC), and area 36cl is typically bounded laterally by the rostral pole of area TF. ...It should be noted that the area encompassed by the perirhinal cortex, as defined here, is substantially larger than illustrated in previous papers on this region ... This due largely to the fact that we have placed the border of the perirhinal cortex with area TE substantially more lateral than is typically the case. The judgement to place the border at this position is based on the findings that the entire region that we have defined as the perirhinal cortex has similar connections both with the entorhinal cortex and with the neocortex. These connections seem to be substantially different from those of the laterally adjacent area TE. Historically, much of what we have labeled perirhinal cortex has been included under the rubric of "inferotemporal cortex" (IT cortex or area TE)." (p. 502)

@InterMapRelations_clean.Comments: It is not clearly stated from which parcellation scheme area STG is adopted. Because IAC87a has been cited in the section of the text where STG is described and D.G. Amaral is a common author of both papers, we chose the parcellation scheme of IAC87a to relate area SA94-STG to subdivisions. SA94-STG extends from the superior lip of the STS to the fundus of the sulcus lateralis and does not include any part of the STS and not the fundus of the sulcus lateralis. Because of that area STG of S94 contains IAC87a' s areas STGr, STGo, STGl, LA, PA, AI, and RA.

publication.title: Perirhinal and parahippocampal cortices of the macaque monkey: Cortical afferents
publication.abstract: Neuropsychological studies have recently demonstrated that the macaque monkey perirhinal (areas 35 and 36) and parahippocampal (areas TH and TF) cortices contribute importantly to normal memory function. Unfortunately, neuroanatomical information concerning the cytoarchitectonic organization and extrinsic connectivity of these cortical regions is meager. We investigated the organization of cortical inputs to the macaque monkey perirhinal and parahippocampal cortices by placing discrete injections of the retrograde tracers fast blue, diamidino yellow, and wheat germ agglutinin conjugated to horseradish peroxidase throughout these areas. We found that the macaque monkey perirhinal and parahippocampal cortices receive different complements of cortical inputs. The major cortical inputs to the perirhinal cortex arise from the unimodal visual areas TE and rostral TEO and from area TF of the parahippocampal cortex. The perirhinal cortex also receives projections from the dysgranular and granular subdivisions of the insular cortex and from area 13 of the orbitofrontal cortex. In contrast, area TF of the parahippocampal cortex receives its strongest input from more caudal visual areas V4, TEO, and caudal TE, as well as prominent inputs from polymodal association cortices, including the retrosplenial cortex and the dorsal bank of the superior temporal sulcus. Area TF also receives projections from areas 7a and LIP of the posterior parietal lobe, insular cortex, and areas 46, 13, 45, and 9 of the frontal lobe. As with area TF, area TH receives substantial projections from the retrosplenial cortex as well as moderate projections from the dorsal bank of the superior temporal sulcus; unlike area TF, area TH receives almost no innervation from areas TE and TEO. It does, however, receive relatively strong inputs from auditory association areas on the convexity of the superior temporal gyrus.
